qas.question: In the 2014 Press Freedom Index, what organization ranked the media environment in Eritrea as the worse of 178 countries?
How did Reporters Without Borders rank the media environment of Eritrea compared to totalitarian North Korea?
What type of media has been banned from Eritrea since 2001?
According to the BBC, which African country is the only one that has no privately owned news media?
According to Reporters Without Borders, where doesn't a single foreign news correspondent live?
In what year was Reporters Without Borders founded?
What country was ranked at the top of the media environment list put together by Reporters Without Borders?

plausible_answers.text: Not a single [foreign correspondent] now lives in Asmara

qas.question: What did The Guardian claim about Eritrea in 2015?
How many native news correspondents are there in Asmara?

context: In its <b5_0>2014<b5_0/> Press Freedom Index, <a0_0>Reporters Without Borders<a0_0/> ranked the media environment in Eritrea at the very bottom of a list of <b8_0>178<b8_0/> countries, <a1_0>just below<a1_0/> totalitarian <b6_0>North Korea<b6_0/>. According to the BBC, "<a3_0>Eritrea<a3_0/> is the only African country to have no privately owned news media", and Reporters Without Borders said of the public media, "[they] do nothing but relay the regime's belligerent and ultra-nationalist discourse. ... <b7_0>Not a single [foreign correspondent] now lives in <a4_0>Asmara<b7_0/><a4_0/>." The state-owned news agency censors news about external events. <a2_0>Independent<a2_0/> media have been banned since 2001. In 2015, The Guardian published an opinion piece claiming,
